/* Classical, Modern Standard, and colloquial Arabic */
Robot - Removing category Languages with over 100 million speakers per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2009 October 5]].
Syriac is included in "Neo-Aramaic" when used as a modern term, and is extinct when used of the liturgical language
macrolanguage is a more technically correct term, see [[macrolanguage]]
"become regarded" rather than "become", since "language" is a cultural and political conception, not linguistically provable

/* Dialects and descendants */ ft:''Colloquial Arabic'' is a collective term ...
/* Dialects and descendants */ ft:''Colloquial'' Arabic is a collective term ...
/*Classical, Modern Standard Arabic and colloquial Arabic
/* Classical and Modern Standard Arabic */ ft:[[Classical Arabic]] (especially from the period of [[Pre-Islamic Arabia]] to that of the [[Abbasid Caliphate]],
/* Classical and Modern Standard Arabic */ ft:[[Classical Arabic]] (especially from the pre-Islamic period to that of the [[Abbasid Caliphate]],
/* Classical and Modern Standard Arabic */ ft:spoken by the Arabic media across [[North Africa]] and the [[Middle East]], and understood by most educated Arabic speakers.
/* Classical and Modern Standard Arabic */ ft:[[Classical Arabic]] (especially from the pre-Islamic to the Abbasid period, including the language of the [[Qur'an]]) ...

/* Classical and Modern Standard Arabic */ ''Arabic'' usually designates one of three main variants: [[Classical Arabic]]; [[Modern Standard Arabic]]; [[Varieties of Arabic|"Colloquial" or "dialectal"

/* Classical and Modern Standard Arabic */ ft: [[Classical Arabic]] (especially from the pre-Islamic to the Abbasid period, including Qur'anic Arabic) is distinct from [[Modern Standard Arabic]] (MSA)
/* Classical and Modern Standard Arabic */ ft:spoken in (predominately [[Roman Catholic]]) [[Malta]] and written with the [[Latin alphabet]].
